si9.svg svg 20924 ALTIMG YJCAT 116000 116000 S0021-9517(25)00065-X 10.1016/j.jcat.2025.116000 Fig. 1 XRD Pattern of all Ni-base catalysts (a) and the detailed XRD patterns of Ni-based catalysts at 2θ of 43–52° (b) and Mo-based catalysts at 2θ of 25–38° (c). Fig. 2 The TEM patterns of the NiMo@HZSM-5 catalyst; the HR-TEM of Ni@HZSM-5 (a) and NiMo@HZSM-5 (b), HAADF-TEM (d-e), elemental mapping of Ni (h), Mo (i), O (j), Si (h), Al (k) and O (l) of the area in (g) HAADF-TEM. Fig. 3 Time-dependent variation curves of conversion and yield of reaction substrates, intermediates, and products, (a) reaction kinetic pathway for the conversion of CMF to HD, (b) CMF, (c) 5-MF, (d) DMF, (e) HD. Fig. 4 The Arrhenius graphs (a) and Gibbs free energy (b) of the steps of the reaction for the conversion of CMF to synthesize HD. Fig. 5 The H2-TPR (a), H2-TPD (b) and NH3-TPD (c) of Ni-based catalysts. Fig. 6 The high-resolution XPS spectrum of Ni2p (a), Mo3d (b) for NiMo@HZSM-5 catalyst vs. monometallic catalysts. Fig. 7 ATR-IR spectrum of CMF (a), 5-MF (b) and BC (c) adsorbed on the NiMo@HZSM-5 and adsorption mode (d) on the NiMo@HZSM-5 surface. Fig. 8 Leaching (a-b) and recovery (c-d) experiments of Ni@HZSM-5 (a, c) and NiMo@HZSM-5 (b, d) catalysts during the synthesis of HD by CMF hydrogenation. Xiamen Key Laboratory of Clean and High-valued Utilization for Biomass College of Energy Xiamen University Xiamen 361102 PR China Graphical abstract Currently, there exists a significant deficiency of reports addressing the direct synthesis of 2,5-hexanedione (HD) from biomass a derivatives 5-Chloromethylfurfural (CMF). The in-situ generation of hydrochloric acid during the hydrogenation process of CMF necessitates catalysts with exceptional acid resistance, which has compelled previous studies to rely on noble-metal catalysts—an approach that poses challenges for scaling up HD production. Herein, this study presents the inaugural report of a non-noble metal nickel-based alloy catalyst synthesized through a straightforward wet impregnation method, which facilitates the efficient catalytic hydrogenation of CMF to produce HD under mild conditions. The results demonstrate that complete conversion of CMF was achieved and an 81.6 % yield of HD was obtained under optimal reaction conditions. In addition, the reaction pathway for synthesizing HD from CMF was elucidated based on the reaction kinetics and gas chromatography-mass spectrometry analysis, accompanied by an in-depth investigation into the reaction mechanism. The molybdenum was incorporated into the catalyst to form alloy components, which significantly enhanced the stability and acid resistance of the catalyst, thereby improving its catalytic performance. This study presents a novel approach for non-noble metal alloy catalysts to efficiently facilitate the conversion of biomass derivatives into downstream chemicals in an acidic environment. Keywords Biomass conversion 5-chloromethylfurfural Alloy catalyst 2,5-hexanedione Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction 2,5-Hexanedione (HD) is a significant organic chemical intermediate that has been extensively utilized in various applications, including pharmaceuticals, fragrances, spray paints, synthetic resins, polymer monomers, solvents, and high-density biofuels [1,2]. The current industrial synthesis of HD primarily involves the coupled hydrolysis of ethyl acetoacetate and ring-opening reaction of 2,5-dimethylfuran (DMF) in the presence of an acid catalyst [3,4]. Given the utilization of renewable resources, the catalytic synthesis of HD from biomass-derived compounds has garnered significant attention in recent years [5,6]. However, most of the reported syntheses of HD using 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) as substrate possessed high reaction temperature, extended reaction time, low yields and predominant reliance on noble metal catalysts. Alternatively, hydrogenolysis of downstream derivatives of furan such as 5-methylfurfural (5-MF) or 5-methylfurfuryl alcohol (5-MFA) and hydrolysis of DMF for ring-opening have been reported to synthesize HD in satisfactory yields (70–99 %) (Table S1). Nevertheless, these methods also encounter common drawbacks, including limited availability of raw materials, cumbersome and expensive synthesis processes, and high cost of noble metal catalysts, which are not conducive to a sustainable production process for HD. Consequently, the advancement of a method for synthesizing HD from abundant, cost-effective, and renewable biomass feedstocks represents a critical scientific issue that warrants immediate attention. 5-Chloromethylfurfural (CMF) is an innovative renewable furan-based derivative that can be synthesized with high yields from glucose, fructose, sucrose, or cellulose through straightforward acid hydrolysis [7–9]. CMF exhibits exceptional reactivity and facilitates subsequent isolation and purification processes due to its pronounced hydrophobicity and remarkable stability, thereby providing a range of significant chemical intermediates for fine chemicals, pharmaceuticals, furan-based polymers, and biofuels. Nevertheless, only a limited number of studies on the direct synthesis of HD from CMF have been reported in the literature. Mascal's group [10] described a two-step synthesis of HD from CMF using DMF as an intermediate, employing Pd/C as a catalyst during the hydrogenolysis of CMF and subsequent hydrolysis of DMF at elevated temperatures (250 °C) to achieve stoichiometric yields of HD. Additionally, Zhang and Li's team [11] presented a method for the direct synthesis of HD from cellulose via CMF as an intermediate within a biphasic system (concentrated HCl/dichloromethane), utilizing Pd/C as a catalyst, which attained up to 64.2 % carbon yield for HD. This approach offers an innovative strategy for synthesizing HD from biomass feedstock; however, it necessitates substantial amounts of concentrated hydrochloric acid and entails high equipment requirements, which are not in line with the concept of green chemistry and are not conducive to the protection of the environment, and need to be warrant further optimization. Recently, Chen et al. [12] reported a direct conversion of CMF to HD using Pd/Al2O3 as the catalyst and PMHS as the hydrogen source, resulting in high yields of up to 78 %. The approach, nonetheless, is constrained by its dependence on noble metal catalysts and the necessity for elevated reaction temperatures. Therefore, it is essential to develop a new technological pathway for the green and efficient synthesis of HD utilizing the novel platform molecule CMF in conjunction with a non-noble metal catalyst. The synthesis of HD from CMF via hydrogenation and ring-opening is anticipated to occur through three major cascade steps: i.e., selective CCl hydrodechlorination, CO hydrogenation/hydrogenolysis, and acid-catalyzed furan ring-opening [12]. Currently, a range of complex catalysts composed of active metals (e.g., Pd, Pt, Ru, Au, Ni, and Cu) supported on acidic materials (e.g., HZSM-5, Amberlyst-15, and Hβ) have exhibited exceptional metal sites and acid sites for hydrogenation/hydrogenolysis and ring-opening reactions, respectively [13–15]. However, the exorbitant cost and limited availability of noble metals have restricted the conversion of biomass derivatives, prompting an increasing number of researchers to prioritize the development and utilization of non-noble metal complex catalysts [16,17]. Among various non-noble metals, nickel-based catalysts are widely employed in the hydrogenation/hydrogenolysis reactions of biomass derivatives due to their excellent hydrogenation performance and cost-effectiveness [18–20]. Kong et al. reported a highly active NiAl2O3 catalyst derived from hydrotalcite-like complexes for the hydrogenation/hydrogenolysis reaction of HMF [21]. This finding demonstrates the feasibility of Ni-based catalysts for the selective hydrogenation of CO, CC, and CO bonds, highlighting their significant potential for application in the catalytic conversion of biomass derivatives. Despite the promising potential, the implementation of conventional nickel-based catalysts in the synthesis of HD from CMF remains a significant challenge. One contributing factor is that the highly dispersed active Ni species exhibit elevated surface free energy on the supports, rendering them susceptible to agglomeration during both preparation and reaction [22]. Previous studies have indicated that introducing an additional metal component enhances the reducibility of nickel oxides, effectively mitigating the aggregation of active nickel sites within the catalyst and consequently yielding higher catalytic activity compared to monometallic catalysts [23–25]. Another challenge arises from the in-situ generation of hydrochloric acid by Cl atoms in the CMF molecule during hydrodechlorination, conventional nickel-based bimetallic catalysts experience a significant loss of activated metal in this acidic environment due to their limited corrosion resistance, which restricts their further application. It has been reported that alloy catalysts possess a wide range of applications in acidic media due to their high acid resistance and reactivity [26,27]. For instance, Zuojun Wei's group reported the preparation of NaBH4-pretreated activated carbon-supported Ni-based catalysts with a Fe promoter and varying Ni loadings for the liquid-phase selective hydrogenation of phthalic anhydride to phthalide. It was found that the incorporation of iron facilitated the formation of a Ni-Fe alloy, enhancing the acid resistance of the catalyst, this catalyst exhibited high catalytic performance even after multiple cycles [28]. Furthermore, the active Ni protected by inert carbon nitride/silicide can significantly mitigate acid corrosion, and the highly dispersed intermetallic NiCo silicide catalysts embedded in a porous carbon matrix demonstrate stability in hydrogenation even within strongly acidic environments [29,30]. Previous studies have enhanced the stability of Ni-based catalysts through the formation of alloys or encapsulated active species. Consequently, there is an urgent need for the development of nickel-based alloy catalysts for the catalytic conversion of biomass derivatives in acidic environments to facilitate the efficient direct synthesis of HD from CMF. Herein, the present study prepared a series of nickel-based catalysts using a wet impregnation method to investigate the role of molybdenum doping in enhancing catalyst performance by forming NiMo bimetallic alloys, as well as examining the synergistic effects between the active metal and support material. Additionally, this study elucidates the reaction pathway and mechanism involved in HD synthesis via CMF hydrogenation. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation The catalysts were synthesized using a wet impregnation method. Specifically, 3.186 g of nickel nitrate trihydrate and 1.183 g of ammonium molybdate tetrahydrate were simultaneously introduced into a 100 mL beaker containing 50 mL of deionized water and stirred for one hour. Subsequently, 3 g of HZSM-5 was incorporated into the mixture, which was then stirred for an additional 8 h to ensure that the metal was uniformly dispersed on the surface of the HZSM-5. After the complete evaporation of water and thorough drying, the material was cooled to room temperature and subsequently ground into a fine powder. Finally, the powdered materials underwent pyrolysis at 550 °C in air for 4 h with a heating rate of 5 °C/min, followed by reduction in a flow of 10 % H2/N2 at the same temperature for 4 h with an identical heating rate to yield the reduced catalyst (denoted as NiMo@HZSM-5). In addition, Ni@HZSM-5 and Mo@HZSM-5 were synthesized by the same method, and different ratios of metal precursors were added to prepare catalysts with different metal ratios. The raw materials utilized in this experiment, the detailed characterization process of the catalysts, and additional experimental results are presented in the supporting material . 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst structural characterization Monometallic Ni, Mo and bimetallic NiMo alloy catalysts were successfully synthesized on HZSM-5 zeolite using a straightforward wet impregnation method, with the corresponding XRD spectra presented in Fig. 1 a. The spectra of all catalysts exhibited the characteristic diffraction peaks of HZSM-5 (PDF# 80-0922), confirming that the metals were effectively loaded onto HZSM-5. For the monometallic Ni@HZSM-5 catalyst, distinct diffraction peaks of metal Ni (PDF# 89-7128) were observed at 44.4, 51.7 and 76.3°, corresponding to the (111), (200) and (220) planes, respectively. The Mo@HZSM-5 catalyst exhibited characteristic reflection peaks at 25.7°, 36.6°, 53.2°, 60.3°, and 66.4°, which corresponded to the (011), (002), (022), (013), and (−231) crystalline planes of MoO2 (PDF# 78-1069). For the bimetallic NiMo@HZSM-5 catalysts, the diffraction peaks of Ni shifted to a lower 2θ angle, from 44.4° to 44.0° for the (111) crystal plane and from 51.7° to 51.4° for (200) plane (Fig. 1b). In contrast, the diffraction peaks of MoO2 shifted to a higher angle (Fig. 1c), indicating that the incorporation of Mo (with a larger radius) into the Ni facilitated electron transfer, thereby altering the crystal structure of the metal and resulting in a lattice-expanded NiMo alloy phase (PDF# 03-1036) [31]. Additionally, the intensity of both Ni and MoO2 characteristic peaks was diminished in the NiMo@HZSM-5 catalyst compared to the monometallic catalysts, indicating that the introduction of Mo could enhance the dispersion of Ni, thereby improving catalyst performance. A high catalytic performance is usually associated with the pore structure of the catalysts. Consequently, pore characterization of the as-synthesized catalysts was performed using N2 adsorption and desorption experiments, with results presented in Fig. S1. The N2 adsorption–desorption isotherm curves indicated that the catalysts exhibited similar structures, featuring specific surface areas ranging from 225–366 m2/g and pore size distributions between 2 ∼ 4 nm (Table S2). This suggests that the catalysts possessed a large specific surface area and comparable mesoporous structures, thereby providing sufficient adsorption sites for selective catalysis. The surface area of all Ni and/or Mo-loaded catalysts decreased compared to that of HZSM-5, indicating that the metals were successfully incorporated onto the surface of the molecular sieve or within its pore channels. This observation is consistent with the reduced intensity of the XRD peaks for these catalysts. The surface morphology and structural characteristics of the catalysts were further examined using scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM), and the findings were illustrated in Fig. 2 & Fig. S2. It is evident that the HZSM-5 exhibits a porous structure (Fig. S2a–b), consistent with the results of N2 adsorption and desorption. In comparison to the HZSM-5, the catalysts loaded with Ni and/or Mo displayed analogous structures, indicating that there was no alteration in the porous architecture of the carrier during the metal doping process, thereby providing ample adsorption sites for the physical adsorption of the catalysts. Furthermore, the high specific surface area and porosity of zeolite enhance metal dispersion, resulting in uniformly distributed metal nanoparticles on the zeolite surface (Fig. S2c–f). This observation indicates that HZSM-5 not only facilitates the homogeneous dispersion of metal nanoparticles but also prevents the aggregation or reaccumulation of active components on its surface. Additionally, energy dispersive spectrometry (EDS) analysis further corroborated that Ni and Mo were uniformly distributed across the molecular sieve surface (Fig. S2h–l). The representative transmission electron microscopy images of the Ni-based catalysts were illustrated in Fig. 2, which clearly demonstrated that the metal nanoparticles are highly dispersed on the surface of HZSM-5 (Fig. 2a–b). For the Ni@HZSM-5 catalyst, the average nanoparticle size was measured at 37.50 ± 0.67 nm (Fig. 2a). In contrast, doping with the Mo element reduced the size of the NiMo@HZSM-5 nanoparticles to 23.02 ± 0.31 nm (Fig. 2b), indicating that the introduction of Mo significantly enhanced catalyst dispersion and consequently decreased nanoparticle size, which aligns with the observed reduction in XRD peak intensity. Furthermore, high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) analysis of NiMo@HZSM-5 revealed the presence of several distinct metal crystalline surfaces within the catalyst (Fig. 2d–f). The A1 and A2 regions exhibited unidirectionally arranged lattice fringes with spacings of 0.2034 nm and 0.2414 nm, corresponding to the Ni (111) and MoO2 (002) crystal planes, respectively. In contrast, the A3 region displayed interspersed lattice fringes indicative of a strong interaction between nickel and molybdenum metals, with a lattice spacing of 0.1793 nm corresponding to the alloy Ni4Mo (3 1 0) crystalline plane, consistent with XRD characterization results. Additionally, the selective area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern (Fig. 2c) confirmed that the NiMo@HZSM-5 nanoparticles exhibited a superposition of Ni (111), MoO2 (0 0 2), and Ni4Mo (3 1 0) crystalline planes, indicating that the catalyst possesses an enhanced crystal structure. Furthermore, energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) analysis of the catalysts (Fig. 2g–l) revealed a uniform distribution of metals across the catalysts, with nickel atoms closely aligning with molybdenum atom distribution, further supporting the formation of a Ni-Mo alloy structure in NiMo@HZSM-5. 3.2 Catalytic performance of Ni-Based catalysts According to previous literature on the synthesis of HD (Table S1), the entire process encompasses three sequential steps: hydrogenation, hydrogenolysis, and ring-opening reactions, necessitating the synergistic interaction between metal and acidic sites. Nickel-based catalysts have garnered significant attention due to their exceptional activity in the hydrogenation/hydrogenolysis processes involving biomass derivatives. Consequently, this study synthesized a series of nickel-based catalysts and evaluated their catalytic performance for the HD synthesis process via CMF hydrogenation, with the results summarized in Table 1 . The results indicated that the yield of HD increased progressively with the enhancement of support acidity (Table 1, entries 2–6), suggesting that acidic sites play a significant role in the synthesis of HD via CMF hydrogenation. Notably, a small amount of HD was also produced when Raney nickel was used as the sole catalyst (Table 1, entry 1). This generation can be attributed to the in-situ formation of hydrochloric acid from Cl− during the hydrodechlorination process of CMF, which positively influences both hydrogenolysis and ring-opening reactions. However, this in-situ production of hydrochloric acid may cause damage to the catalyst, necessitating high acid resistance for effective catalytic performance. To mitigate the protonated acid generated in the reaction system, an equivalent amount of CaCO3 was incorporated into the current reaction (Table 1, entry 7). As anticipated, the yield of HD increased by approximately 10 % with the Ni@HZSM-5 catalyst. Additionally, while the addition of CaCO3 modified the acidity (pH) of the reaction system to some extent, a notable greenish coloration of the reaction solution was also observed (Fig. S3a–b). This observation indicates that there remains significant metal loss of active nickel within this reaction system (consistent with ICP results presented in Table S3), suggesting that simply adding CaCO3 does not fundamentally resolve the issue of activated metal loss from the catalyst. Furthermore, various metallic elements were incorporated into the Ni-based catalysts to create bimetallic or alloy structures (Table 1, entries 8–10). It was found that the introduction of Mo significantly enhanced the reaction, however, the yield of HD remained negligible when using Mo@HZSM-5 as a catalyst (Table 1, entry 11). This finding indicates that incorporating Mo into the catalyst improved the stability of the Ni-based system and subsequently enhanced its reactivity. Similarly, further enhancement in HD yield was observed by adding CaCO3 during the reaction process with NiMo@HZSM-5 as the catalyst, resulting in a colorless reaction solution (Fig. S3c–d). This observation suggests that there was no significant loss of active metal from the catalyst, thereby reinforcing that Mo incorporation increased catalyst stability. In addition, the difference in activity between Ni@HZSM-5 and NiMo@HZSM-5 was not significant in the absence of CaCO3 addition, but when experimented again with the recovered catalyst (Table 1, entries 15–16), the activity of Ni@HZSM-5 catalyst was significantly reduced, indicating a serious loss of active metal, while the activity of the NiMo@HZSM-5 catalyst had no obvious change, which further proved that Mo could increase the stability of the catalyst. Consequently, NiMo@HZSM-5 was selected as the catalyst for subsequent investigations, and process optimization was conducted for various parameters (reaction temperature, catalyst dosage, solvent type, the ratio of Ni and Mo, and CaCO3 dosage) during this reaction (Fig. S4). Under optimal conditions, CMF was completely converted with a maximum HD yield of 81.6 %. Specifically, in case of catalysts with different proportions of metals, when Ni content is increased, it leads to over-hydrogenation of products and intermediates (Fig. S5b) with reduced selectivity, whereas when Mo content is increased, it leads to the generation of mostly intermediates due to the reduction of hydrogenation activity. Therefore, based on the experimental phenomena and literature reports [32,33], when the ratio of nickel to molybdenum is 1:1, which contributes to the formation of highly uniformly dispersed Ni nanoparticles of the catalyst, reduces metal agglomeration and facilitates the activation of hydrogenation sites, subsequent experiments were carried out using the identical ratio of metals. It is also necessary to conduct experiments at appropriate reaction temperatures and H2 pressures, which can effectively avoid over-hydrogenation or polymerization of intermediates and products. In addition, the acid resistance of the catalysts was also examined (Table 1, entries 17–19), and the performance of the catalysts maintained a relatively high catalytic effect using 1 mmol/L HCl treatment and addition of an extra 0.5–1 mmol of HCl in the reaction system, respectively. The aforementioned experimental results demonstrated that NiMo@HZSM-5 exhibits remarkable catalytic efficiency for the hydrogenation of CMF to produce HD. Consequently, we conducted comprehensive investigations into the metal and acidic sites of the catalysts to elucidate the key factors governing the entire catalytic process. Initially, when CMF served as the substrate and the Ni-Mo catalyst was employed, the predominant product was 5-MF, accompanied by trace amounts of HD. However, the yield of HD significantly increased to 47.3 % upon physically mixing the Ni-Mo catalyst with molecular sieves (Table 1 entries 13–14), indicating that acidic sites are crucial for HD synthesis. Subsequently, minimal conversion of the reactants was observed when 5-MF/5-MFA served as the substrate and Ni-Mo and HZSM-5 were employed individually as catalysts (Table S4, entries 5–8). In contrast, a more favorable yield of HD was achieved by incorporating metal catalysts alongside HZSM-5 when utilizing 5-MFA as the reactant (Table S4, entries 2 and 9). This result indicates that the hydrogenation of CO and the subsequent hydrogenolysis of C-OH are synergistically regulated by both metal and acidic sites. Finally, satisfactory yields of HD were achieved with HZSM-5 used exclusively as the catalyst when DMF served as the reactant (Table S4, entry 4). Collectively, these results demonstrate that the metal sites of the catalysts primarily facilitate hydrodechlorination of CMF and hydrogenolysis of 5-MF, while the acidic sites are predominantly involved in the hydrogenolysis of 5-MF and ring-opening reactions involving DMF. Additionally, the reaction system is a critical factor for the efficient synthesis of HD from CMF, and solvent screening indicated that dichloromethane/H2O represents the optimal reaction environment for this process. To investigate the effect of this biphasic reaction system on the overall process, experiments were initially conducted in a system containing only the organic phase, which demonstrated that CMF was completely converted; however, the product consisted solely of 5-MF. Subsequently, further conversion to downstream products failed when both 5-MF and DMF were employed as substrates for the reaction (Table S4, entries 10–12). Finally, the generation of HD was observed in the aqueous phase system when both 5-MF and DMF were used as substrates, especially, with HD exhibiting the highest selectivity when DMF served as the substrate (Table S4, entries 13–14). This finding underscores the critical role of water in the reaction system for both the hydrogenation/hydrogenolysis of 5-MF and the ring-opening reaction of DMF. The overall reaction pathway commences with the hydrodechlorination of CMF in a dichloromethane phase, yielding 5-MF, followed by hydrogenation/hydrogenolysis occurring at the interface between organic and aqueous phases to produce DMF. Finally, hydrolysis and ring-opening of DMF take place in the aqueous phase, resulting in the formation of the target product HD. 3.3 Reaction kinetics study As mentioned above, the synthesis of HD from CMF involves C-Cl hydrodechlorination, CO hydrogenation/hydrogenolysis, and DMF hydrolysis ring-opening steps, with the products and intermediates confirmed by GC–MS analysis (Fig. S6). Additionally, an alternative pathway for the generation of HD involving CO hydrogenation to 5-MFA, subsequent ring-opening of 5-MFA to form 3-hexene-2,5-dione (HED), and a CC hydrogenation step has been explored in previous reports [34]. A kinetic study of the entire process was conducted to investigate the reaction pathway for the preparation of HD from CMF within the current reaction system. The intermediate product MFA and the ring-opening product HED were not detected through reaction kinetics or GC–MS analysis. To further elucidate the reaction pathway, 5-MF, 5-MFA, and DMF were utilized as substrates in the current system (Table S4, entries 1–3), and the results indicated that all of them yielded excellent HD production. However, 5-MFA was not detected during the preparation of HD via CMF hydrogenation, likely due to rapid hydrogenolysis of 5-MFA in this catalytic system, followed by direct hydrolysis and ring-opening of DMF to produce HD. Consequently, a reasonable reaction pathway for the generation of HD via CMF hydrogenation was established based on the aforementioned results, as illustrated in Fig. 3 a. Subsequently, the time-dependent variation curves of CMF hydrogenation products were further investigated at 80 to 110 °C, and each series of data was obtained after several repetitions of the experiments, with the results presented in Fig. 3b–e. From these figures, it can be concluded that all reaction intermediates and products exhibited characteristics consistent with continuous reactions, which increased firstly and then decreased with the prolongation of time, moreover, an increase in reaction temperature favored the production of HD. It is noteworthy that CMF was basically completely converted within 1 h, indicating that the hydrodechlorination reaction of CMF was a fast reaction, and a trace amount of the intermediate product DMF was detected, suggesting that the hydrolysis and ring-opening reaction of DMF was also a fast process. It was preliminarily speculated that the hydrogenation/hydrogenolysis of 5-MF to yield DMF represents the rate-controlling step in the overall process. Based on the sequential kinetic behaviors of dechlorination, hydrogenation/hydrogenolysis, and ring-opening for CMF, a quasi-first-order kinetic equation has been proposed in this study, with the reaction rates for each step expressed by Eqs. (1)–(4). Integration of the above differential equations obtained the corresponding product concentration expressions, as illustrated in Eqs. (5)–(8). The correlation between kinetic constants and temperature is as follows: (9) k i = A i ∙ e x p - Ea i RT ( i = 1 , 2 , 3 ) where Ai and Eai represent the pre-exponential factor (h−1) and the reaction activation energy (kJ/mol) for the i step of the reaction, respectively; T represents the reaction temperature, K; and R represents the ideal gas constant, 8.314 J/(mol·K). Based on the least-squares regression, the parameters in the above derived theoretical formulas (i.e., Eqs. (5)–(8)) can be calculated out by using the data presented in Fig. 3b–e for fitting. Notably, most of the experimental data points were randomly selected for modeling based on multiple repetitions of the experiments, covering as much as possible the range of substrates, intermediates, and products, and the reaction rate constants in Eq. (9) were determined at a confidence level of 95 %, with the best-fit values shown in Table S5 and Fig. 4 a. As shown in Table S5, the reaction rate constants increased with elevated reaction temperatures (80–110 °C), indicating that higher temperature favors the hydrogenation of CMF to HD. The Arrhenius fitting curve (Fig. 4a) revealed the activation energy for the CMF hydrodechlorination reaction (CMF to 5-MF) was only 18.92 kJ/mol, while that for DMF hydrolysis and ring-opening (DMF to HD) was 23.40 kJ/mol, both of which were significantly lower than the activation energy of 46.41 kJ/mol required for the hydrogenation/hydrogenolysis reaction of 5-MF (5-MF to DMF). This indicated that both CMF hydrodechlorination and DMF ring-opening were rapid reaction steps facilitated by the combined action of active metal sites and acidic sites, consistent with the kinetic process depicted in Fig. 3. In contrast, the hydrogenolysis of 5-MF to DMF necessitated the highest activation energy, suggesting that this step was the rate-determining within this reaction pathway. Additionally, the correlation between the predicted and experimental values of the model for each stage of CMF conversion to HD was plotted based on the fitted model parameters presented in Table S4 and Eqs. (5)–(9) (Fig. S7). The results indicated that the R-squared values of the prediction models were all greater than 0.99, demonstrating a significant correlation between the predicted and measured data. To further validate the robustness of the model, the relative deviation (RD) between predicted and measured values at various temperatures was presented in Fig. S8. As illustrated, the relative deviations were maintained within 10.0 %, with a majority falling below 5.0 %, indicating that the proposed model effectively describes the conversion of CMF to HD. To further elucidate the complexity of each reaction step involved in the hydrogenation of CMF for HD synthesis under specified reaction conditions, a detailed thermodynamic analysis of the products throughout the entire hydrogenation process was conducted to determine the Gibbs free energy associated with this overall reaction (Fig. 4b). The findings revealed that the Gibbs free energy for the hydrogenolysis of 5-MF to DMF, followed by ring-opening to yield HD, was significantly lower than that for the sequential processes involving hydrogenation of 5-MF to 5-MFA, subsequent ring-opening to HED, and final hydrogenation to HD. This observation implies that the former pathway exhibits enhanced thermodynamic favorability, thereby offering additional support for the previously discussed kinetic mechanism. 3.4 Reaction mechanism The interaction between the metal and the support may influence the chemical state of the metal, which in turn affects the performance of catalysts. Therefore, the reducibility of the as-prepared Ni-based catalysts was investigated using H2-TPR, with results illustrated in Fig. 5 a. For the monometallic Ni@HZSM-5 catalyst, two characteristic reduction peaks were observed at Tmax values of 123.2 °C and 275.8 °C, respectively. The first peak was attributed to the reduction of bulk NiO with a weak interaction with the support, while the second peak appeared at 275.8 °C corresponding to the reduction of dispersed nickel oxide exhibiting a strong interaction with HZSM-5 [35]. The Mo@HZSM-5 catalyst exhibited three characteristic reduction peaks at Tmax values of 326.1 °C, 464.8 °C and 726.6 °C, respectively. The first two peaks were attributed to the gradual reduction from Mo6+ through Mo5+ to Mo4+, while the third peak was associated with the reduction process from Mo4+ to metallic Mo. In contrast, the NiMo@HZSM-5 catalyst exhibited four distinct reduction peaks at Tmax values of 100.3 °C, 157.1 °C, 339.5 °C, and 641.1 °C. The reduction peak at 100.3 °C was attributed to the reduction of dispersed NiO, while the peaks at 157.1 °C and 339.5 °C were associated with the stepwise reduction from Mo6+ via Mo5+ to Mo4+. The final peak observed in the NiMo@HZSM-5 catalyst at 641.1 °C resulted from the reduction of MoO2 to metallic Mo [36]. The results demonstrated that the reduction temperatures of each metal in the bimetallic catalysts were shifted to lower values, which can be attributed to the strong binding and electron transfer between Ni and Mo. This interaction improved the electronic structure of the catalysts, facilitating their reduction. Consequently, the hydrogen adsorption and activation capacity of the catalysts was enhanced. In addition, although the reduction temperature of H2-TPR is higher than that of the catalyst preparation, it can also be seen that Mo4+ reduces from 457.4 °C (Fig. 5a), which would also lead to the formation of partial alloys during the reduction process, which is in agreement with the results of the literature that reported that partial alloys can be formed even in a non-ideal condition [37,38]. The catalytic performance of catalysts is significantly influenced by the quantity of hydrogen adsorbed at the active surface sites. Consequently, H2-TPD was employed to investigate the dissociative adsorption capacity of hydrogen on nickel-based catalysts (Fig. 5b and Table S6). It has been documented that hydrogen dissociates on the surface of Ni-based catalysts, with desorption peaks revealing distinct chemical adsorption patterns characterized by weakly and moderately strong adsorption peaks, respectively. Following hydrogen activation on the catalyst surface, a portion of H2 is directly adsorbed onto the metal, while another fraction migrates to adjacent supports via the hydrogen spillover effect. The NiMo@HZSM-5 alloy catalyst displayed two distinct types of desorption peaks at 105.2 °C (linear adsorption) and 296.7 °C, 456.6 °C (bridge adsorption), which correspond to the weakly adsorbed hydrogen peaks at individual Ni sites and the hydrogen spillover generated from Ni, respectively [39]. The intensity of the bridge adsorption peak was significantly enhanced compared to Ni@HZSM-5 and Mo@HZSM-5 (Table S6). This modification can be attributed to hydrogen spillover, wherein H2-dissociated hydrogen atoms on Ni nanoparticles migrate across the surface of Mo elements, accompanied by the reduction of high-valence Mo6+ to low-valent states, consistent with the H2-TPR results. To validate the aforementioned findings, WO3 and the as-prepared catalysts were physically mixed in water under a hydrogen atmosphere (Fig. S9). The results indicated that yellow WO3 was effectively reduced to blue WO3-x when combined with NiMo@HZSM-5, however, no significant color change of WO3 was observed with either Ni-@HZSM-5 or Mo@HZSM-5 catalysts. It is well established that the acidic sites of catalysts are crucial for enhancing catalytic activity, and the relationship between the surface acidity of the catalysts and their catalytic performance was further examined using the NH3-TPD technique. As illustrated in Fig. 5c and Table S7, the NH3-TPD spectra of all catalysts exhibited two distinct types of desorption peaks centered at 80–100 °C and 310–340 °C, which were classified as weak and medium-strong acid sites, respectively [40,41]. For the monometallic Ni@HZSM-5 and Mo@HZSM-5 catalysts, the NH3 adsorption–desorption curves and acidity were not significantly different from those of the support. However, the simultaneous incorporation of Ni and Mo into the catalysts resulted in significant enhancements in the NH3 adsorption–desorption profiles, indicating robust interactions between Ni and Mo that altered the surface structure of the catalysts and led to a marked increase in their acidic sites. This provided sufficient active sites for the hydrogenolysis of CO bonds in 5-MF and for the ring-opening of DMF, which aligns with findings reported in existing literature [42,43]. Furthermore, a correlation was established between the total acidity and the maximum adsorption of CMF as well as the yield of HD (Fig. S10). As expected, all parameters demonstrated a positive linear correlation, suggesting that the increased acidity of the catalyst enhanced substrate adsorption efficiency, thereby elevating the yield of HD. It is widely acknowledged that pyridine interacts with acidic sites, resulting in catalyst deactivation. Upon introducing pyridine into the current reaction, only a substantial amount of 5-MF was produced. Furthermore, when pyridine was incorporated into reactions utilizing 5-MF and DMF as substrates respectively, a notable decrease in conversion was observed. This finding corroborates our earlier hypothesis. The aforementioned experiments demonstrated that the active metals Ni and Mo play a crucial role in the CMF hydrogenation process. Given that these catalysts exhibit comparable metal nanoparticle size and dispersity, it can be inferred that their hydrogenation activity primarily arises from modifications to their hydrogenation sites. Consequently, the electronic valence states of Ni and Mo within the catalysts were characterized using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), with high-resolution deconvolution XPS peaks for each element presented in Fig. 6 . For the monometallic Ni@HZSM-5 catalyst, the peaks observed at 853.09 eV and 870.97 eV were assigned to the 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 states of Ni0, respectively, while those at 856.15 eV and 874.15 eV corresponded to the 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 states of nickel oxide (NiOx), respectively [44]. Additionally, two satellite peaks were detected at 861.53 eV and 880.27 eV, suggesting that spontaneous surface oxidation occurred upon exposure of the catalyst to atmospheric conditions. In comparison to Ni@HZSM-5, the signals of all nickel species in the NiMo@HZSM-5 catalyst exhibited a shift to lower binding energy upon doping with Mo atoms (Fig. 6a). Specifically, the peaks corresponding to the Ni2p3/2 emission spectra for metallic Ni0 and Ni2+ shifted from 853.09 eV to 852.75 eV and from 856.15 eV to 856.04 eV, respectively. Excluding any influence of crystal structure changes on electronic energy bands, this shift can be attributed to partial electron transfer from molybdenum to nickel, indicating an increased electron cloud density for Ni in NiMo alloys. Notably, all molybdenum species in the NiMo@HZSM-5 catalyst displayed a tendency towards higher binding energy compared with Mo@HZSM-5, which further supports the notion of electron transfer from Mo atoms to adjacent Ni atoms. Furthermore, the increased ratio of Ni0/Ni2+ in NiMo@HZSM-5 compared to monometallic Ni@HZSM-5 (Table S8) indicates that the incorporation of Mo promotes the reduction of NiOx, which aligns with the H2-TPR results. Meanwhile, the proportion of low-valent (Mo4+, Mo5+) molybdenum in the NiMo@HZSM-5 catalyst was also elevated than that in Mo@HZSM-5. It has been reported that higher concentration of low-valent molybdenum can further facilitate the hydrogenation reaction [45]. Moreover, the low-valent Mo4+ and Mo5+ species can act as Lewis’s acid sites, which are known to stabilize reaction intermediates and can reduce the activation energy required for the reaction to proceed, thereby enhancing the reaction rate, which is consistent with the results reported in the literature [46]. These species also can facilitate proton transfer, acting as proton shuttles and improving reaction kinetics, leading to more efficient conversion of reactants to products. The interaction between Mo4+ and Mo5+ species and Ni sites can lead to synergistic effects, enhancing the overall catalytic activity by modifying the electronic properties of Ni sites [47]. To further elucidate the relationship between the chemical states of Ni and Mo species with the synthesis HD of CMF hydrogenation, the recovered catalysts were subjected to XPS analysis following reactions conducted under 1 MPa N2 or H2 atmosphere (labeled as Recycled- NiMo@HZSM-5-N2 and Recycled- NiMo@HZSM-5). The high-valence metals of only Ni2+ and Mo6+ along with trace amounts of Mo4+ and Mo5+ were detected in Recycled- NiMo@HZSM-5-N2. Conversely, the metal valences observed in the Recycled- NiMo@HZSM-5 catalysts did not significantly differ from those of the pristine NiMo@HZSM-5 (Fig. S11 and Table S8). This suggests that a few low-valent Ni0 and Mo4+/Mo5+ species were oxidized to higher valence states during the CMF hydrogenation process, subsequently reverting to their original electronically equivalent states in a hydrogen atmosphere, and the metal content of the recovered catalysts was not significantly different from that of the original catalysts. In contrast, under nitrogen conditions, these elements remained predominantly in high-valent states, leading to less effective hydrogenation of the catalysts. Therefore, it is hypothesized that redox processes involving Ni0/Ni2+ and Mo4+/Mo5+/Mo6+ are integral to HD production via CMF hydrogenation. To validate this hypothesis, NiMo@HZSM-5 and Recycled- NiMo@HZSM-5-N2 were utilized as catalysts for comparative analysis. As shown in Table S9, entries 4–5, the catalytic performance of both NiMo@HZSM-5 and Recycled- NiMo@HZSM-5-N2 for the hydrogenation of CMF to HD was negligible under a hydrogen-free atmosphere. In contrast, their catalytic activity was restored under a 1 MPa hydrogen atmosphere (Table S9, entries 1–2). This indicates that the high-valent metals in the catalysts were partially reduced to low-valent states in the presence of hydrogen, thereby facilitating the hydrogenation reaction. Notably, the activity of NiMo@HZSM-5 exceeded that of Recycled- NiMo@HZSM-5-N2 under nitrogen conditions, suggesting that low-valent metals (Ni0, Mo4+ and/or Mo5+) contributed significantly to hydrogenation capacity. Similarly, Recycled- NiMo@HZSM-5 demonstrated limited catalytic performance for the hydrogenation of CMF under nitrogen conditions (Table S9, entry 6), whereas its performance was restored in a hydrogen environment (Table S9, entry 3). These results indicate that the redox cycling processes involving Ni0/Ni2+ and Mo4+/Mo5+/Mo6+ were clearly observed during the hydrogenation of CMF to HD. According to our knowledge, the in situ generated hydrogen atoms from catalyst-activated hydrogen molecules, characterized by asymmetric H+ H− pairs, preferentially facilitate the CO hydrogenation over that of the CC bonds within the furan group [48,49]. To elucidate the selective catalytic mechanism underlying the hydrogenation of CMF to generate HD, molecular insights into the interaction between CMF and NiMo@HZSM-5 were employed by attenuated total reflectance-infrared spectroscopy (ATR-IR) (Fig. 7 ). The infrared spectrum of CMF exhibits distinct absorption peaks at 730 cm−1 (attributed to C6Cl7), 773 cm−1, 974 cm−1, 1021 cm−1, 1190 cm−1, and 1520 cm−1 (corresponding to the furan ring as well as C8C2C3 & C6C5C4 and C2C3 & C4C5, respectively) and 1693 cm−1 (associated with C8O9). As illustrated in Fig. 7a, the adsorption of CMF on the surface of NiMo@HZSM-5 resulted in red-shifts for the CO and CCl groups from 1693 cm−1 to 1674 cm−1 and from 728 cm−1 to 720 cm−1, respectively. In contrast, no significant shift was observed for the characteristic peaks of the furan ring, indicating that NiMo@HZSM-5 exerts a strong adsorption effect on the CO and CCl groups of CMF. The selective adsorption of CCl and CO on NiMo@HZSM-5 was further examined using the ATR-IR technique, employing benzyl chloride (BC) and 5-methylfurfural (5-MF) as substrates, as illustrated in Fig. 7b–c. As anticipated, the characteristic absorption peaks of CCl and CO exhibited a red shift in the infrared spectra of catalysts adsorbed with BC and 5-MF, respectively. Notably, no significant changes were observed in the peaks corresponding to the benzene and furan rings, indicating that NiMo@HZSM-5 demonstrated strong adsorption capabilities for both CCl bonds and CO groups. Consequently, it was preliminarily hypothesized that CMF was adsorbed parallelly onto NiMo@HZSM-5 through its CCl and CO terminals. To further elucidate the strength of selective adsorption of CCl and CO on the NiMo@HZSM-5 catalyst, adsorption kinetic experiments involving BC, 5-MF, and CMF were conducted on the surface of NiMo@HZSM-5 (Fig. S12a). The results indicated that the adsorption capacity for BC or CMF was significantly greater than that for 5-MF. To investigate the competitive adsorption behavior of CCl and/or aldehyde groups on NiMo@HZSM-5, additional experiments were performed using a mixture of BC and 5-MF as substrates (Fig. S12b). Notably, it was observed that BC exhibited a superior adsorption capacity on the surface of NiMo@HZSM-5. These findings clearly demonstrate competitive adsorption between CCl and the aldehyde group in CMF. Furthermore, the aforementioned reaction kinetics indicate that CMF rapidly converts to 5-MF when catalyzed by NiMo@HZSM-5. Consequently, it is hypothesized that following the adsorption of CMF onto NiMo@HZSM-5, rapid hydrodechlorination occurs to yield 5-MF within the current reaction system, followed by desorption of the methyl group from the catalyst surface. This process transitions the adsorption model from parallel to vertical orientation via the CO terminal, subsequently facilitating selective hydrogenolysis and ring-opening to produce HD, thereby effectively mitigating undesired over-hydrogenation reactions of the furan ring. Furthermore, to investigate the synergistic effects of active metals within NiMo@HZSM-5, adsorption kinetic experiments involving CMF and 5-MF were conducted on Ni@HZSM-5 and Mo@HZSM-5, respectively, as illustrated in Fig. S12c–d. The results indicated a pronounced competitive adsorption of CMF and 5-MF, as well as the corresponding adsorption amounts on the surfaces of Ni@HZSM-5 and NiMo@HZSM-5 in comparison to Mo@HZSM-5. Consequently, it was speculated that the Ni species exhibit a stronger adsorption affinity for the reactants. To validate this hypothesis, the adsorption behaviors of CMF and 5-MF on Ni@HZSM-5 and Mo@HZSM-5 were further examined using ATR-IR, as illustrated in Fig. S13. As expected, the CCl bonds of CMF exhibited a significant red shift on the surfaces of both Ni@HZSM-5 and Mo@HZSM-5 (Fig. S13a & c), while the CO bonds showed no substantial shift on the surface of Mo@HZSM-5. This observation suggests that the catalysts exert a stronger chemical adsorption effect on the CCl bonds (Fig. S13c–d). These findings confirm that Ni species serve as the primary active sites for high reactivity through preferential adsorption of the CCl bond in CMF alongside simultaneous adsorption of the CO group (Fig. S13e), whereas Mo species play a negligible role regarding the CO group, which aligns with observed activities of Ni@HZSM-5 and Mo@HZSM-5 in catalyzing the conversion of CMF to HD. In conclusion, based on the aforementioned experimental results, this study proposes a plausible reaction pathway for the hydrogenation of CMF to HD via NiMo@HZSM-5. As illustrated in Scheme 1 , initially, the CCl terminus in CMF preferentially competes with CO for adsorption onto the metal Ni0 sites on the surface of the NiMo@HZSM-5 catalyst. Concurrently, H2 molecules generate hydrogen atoms in situ under the influence of activated metal Ni; these hydrogen atoms rapidly combine with the CCl terminus to facilitate hydrodechlorination and produce 5-MF. This result has been demonstrated by a D2 isotope labeling method in a previous work [50], which showed that hydrogen atoms in the hydrogen molecule preferentially undergo a hydrodechlorination reaction with Cl and traced the subsequent hydrogenation process. The resulting methyl group is desorbed from the catalyst surface, leading to a transition of the adsorption mode from flat to vertical. Subsequently, activated hydrogen atoms further participate in hydrogenation/hydrogenolysis of CO within an acidic environment and water to yield DMF. Ultimately, DMF undergoes a ring-opening reaction at the interface between organic and aqueous phases under acidic conditions to generate HD, which subsequently desorbs into the organic phase. Through D2O isotope labeling experiments (Fig. S14) and literature reports [51], water plays a crucial role in the DMF ring-opening process, where hydrogen atoms in water are transferred to HD molecules, which is also consistent with the result that HD cannot be generated in an anhydrous environment. Therefore, in this study, the H2 molecule mainly acts in the hydrodechlorination and hydrogenation/hydrogenolysis steps, and the final water molecule is mainly involved in the ring-opening of DMF. The high-valence oxides (Ni2+, Mo6+) generated during the hydrogenation process are reduced to their original states in this hydrogen atmosphere and can be continuously recycled for the aforementioned hydrogenation process. Additionally, the Mo element in the catalyst enhanced the stability and acid resistance of the catalyst throughout the entire reaction process, thereby promoting multiple recycling opportunities. 3.5 Leaching and recoverability properties The leaching experiments for the Ni@HZSM-5 and NiMo@HZSM-5 catalysts were conducted separately to assess the stability of the Ni-based catalysts during the reaction, with results presented in Fig. 8 a–b. The catalyst was separated after 2 h and the reaction was extended to 8 h. Unsurprisingly, the yield of HD continuously increased in the reaction system following the removal of the Ni@HZSM-5 catalyst, indicating the leaching of active metals from the Ni@HZSM-5 into the reaction solution, which facilitated further conversion. In contrast, no significant change in HD yield was observed in the reaction system with the NiMo@HZSM-5 catalyst removed, suggesting negligible leaching of active species from NiMo@HZSM-5 into the resulting solution and demonstrating its excellent stability. To confirm this conclusion, the metal concentrations of the reaction mixture after the reaction of the NiMo@HZSM-5 system were subsequently determined using ICP-MS (Table S10). The concentration of Ni and Mo ions in the reaction solution was only 13.20 μg/L and 4.53 μg/L, respectively, which indicates that the loss of active metal in the catalyst is negligible and the catalyst has excellent stability, consistent with the results reported in the literature [52]. Furthermore, elemental analysis results indicated that the proportions of active components in both fresh and recovered NiMo@HZSM-5 catalysts remained essentially unchanged, whereas significant variations were observed in Ni@HZSM-5 (Table S3), confirming that the incorporation of Mo has substantially enhanced the stability of the catalysts. Additionally, the recycling experiments for Ni@HZSM-5 and NiMo@HZSM-5 catalysts were conducted separately. After the initial run, the catalysts were recovered via centrifugation, followed by extensive washing with water and ethanol, vacuum-drying, and preparation for subsequent runs. The recovered catalysts were characterized using XRD, FT-IR, SEM, and XPS (Fig. S11 & 15–17), with results indicating no significant difference between the NiMo@HZSM-5 and fresh catalysts; however, the structure of Ni@HZSM-5 underwent dramatic changes. The recycling tests further revealed that Ni@HZSM-5 exhibited unsatisfactory reutilization due to substantial loss of active metals, while the yield of HD from NiMo@HZSM-5 remained above 70 % after five cycles (Fig. 8c–d). However, when recycling was continued, it was found that the product yield continued to decrease, which may be due to the accumulation of carbon in the catalyst pores. For this reason, the catalyst recovered after several cycles was calcined in a muffle furnace to remove the carbon, and then reduced in a tube furnace to obtain the regenerated catalyst. As anticipated, the regenerated NiMo@HZSM-5 demonstrated excellent catalytic activity with complete conversion of CMF and an HD yield exceeding 80 % (recycled 10 times). In contrast, the activity of regenerated Ni@HZSM-5 did not show significant improvement, indicating that the loss of active nickel metal in this catalyst was irreversible and could not be restored through simple calcination reduction. This further underscores that the incorporation of Mo enhanced both the structural integrity and stability as well as the recyclability of the catalyst. 4 Conclusion In summary, current research on the direct synthesis of 2,5-hexanedione from biomass derivatives under mild reaction conditions is limited, and the extensive use of noble metal catalysts hinders the development of a sustainable process for HD production. In this study, we present for the first time the synthesis of a non-noble metal nickel-based alloy catalyst through a straightforward wet impregnation method, which facilitates efficient catalytic hydrogenation of biomass-derived CMF for HD production under mild conditions. The results demonstrated that this nickel-based catalyst achieves complete conversion of CMF under optimal reaction conditions, with an HD yield reaching as high as 81.6 %. Additionally, a kinetic study of the entire reaction process was conducted to elucidate the reaction pathway and identify the rate-limiting step in the hydrogenation of CMF for HD production. The overall reaction process was governed by both hydrogenation sites and acidic sites, where hydrogenation sites primarily facilitate the hydrodechlorination of CMF and the hydrogenolysis of 5-MF, while acidic sites were chiefly involved in the hydrogenolysis of 5-MF and the ring-opening reaction of DMF. Moreover, the composition of the reaction system serves as a critical determinant for efficient HD synthesis from CMF, with water playing an essential role in both the hydrogenolysis process of 5-MF and the ring-opening mechanism of DMF. Furthermore, the incorporation of molybdenum into the Ni-based catalyst results in the formation of an alloy component, which significantly enhances both the stability and acid resistance of the catalyst while improving the overall catalytic performance of the reaction system. coredata.dc:description: Currently, there exists a significant deficiency of reports addressing the direct synthesis of 2,5-hexanedione (HD) from biomass a derivatives 5-Chloromethylfurfural (CMF). The in-situ generation of hydrochloric acid during the hydrogenation process of CMF necessitates catalysts with exceptional acid resistance, which has compelled previous studies to rely on noble-metal catalysts—an approach that poses challenges for scaling up HD production. Herein, this study presents the inaugural report of a non-noble metal nickel-based alloy catalyst synthesized through a straightforward wet impregnation method, which facilitates the efficient catalytic hydrogenation of CMF to produce HD under mild conditions. The results demonstrate that complete conversion of CMF was achieved and an 81.6 % yield of HD was obtained under optimal reaction conditions. In addition, the reaction pathway for synthesizing HD from CMF was elucidated based on the reaction kinetics and gas chromatography-mass spectrometry analysis, accompanied by an in-depth investigation into the reaction mechanism. The molybdenum was incorporated into the catalyst to form alloy components, which significantly enhanced the stability and acid resistance of the catalyst, thereby improving its catalytic performance. This study presents a novel approach for non-noble metal alloy catalysts to efficiently facilitate the conversion of biomass derivatives into downstream chemicals in an acidic environment.
